pr_title: WIP: Convert MeetingScheduling example to ConstraintStreams

timeline.bodyText:
The problem lies in from(MeetingAssignment.class). There are no such instances, because you never set any value to MeetingAssignment.room planning variable. from() therefore treats those instances as uninitialized, and skips them. Two solutions:

use fromUnfiltered() in the constraint provider or
initialize your entities properly in the test.

Also, I suggest you make sure your @PlanningIds are never null, because the following PR will start enforcing that pretty soon:
triceo#14
I have not reviewed any other constraints as I assumed the same problem would be plagueing them as well.
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: I suggest you create constructors for the facts/entities so that you are forced to always provide all the information that must not be null. (As opposed to hoping you always remember to include all the setters.)
replies.author: triceo

timeline.bodyText: Please remember to include in the given(...) call all the facts relevant to the problem. Not including them here means you won't be able to use them in join(), exists() etc.

replies.bodyText: How does this work on TriConstraintStreams? I'm guessing something like: equal(RequiredAttendance::getMeeting, MeetingAssignment::getMeeting). But in this case wouldn't the RequiredAttendance being compared be ambiguous, since there are two of them joined in this stream?
replies.author: cuijulian

replies.bodyText:
The joiner will always take all the arguments from the left, and the single argument from the right.
So this would be something like equal((lra, rra) -> lra.getMeeting(), MeetingAssignment::getMeeting).
